title-group.article-title: Oxytelus acriculiclypeatus, a New Species of Oxytelus Gravenhorst, 1802 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Oxytelinae) from Borneo

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Oxytelus acriculiclypeatus
, a New Species of
Oxytelus Gravenhorst, 1802
( Coleoptera : Staphylinidae : Oxytelinae ) from Borneo
1 Hebei Collaborative Innovation Center for Eco‐Environment, College of Life Sciences, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang, Hebei Province 050024, China .

2 Hebei Key Laboratory of Animal Physiology, Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Shijiazhuang, Hebei Province , China .
Ễ
lianges.luex@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-7533-6244

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new species,
Oxytelus acriculiclypeatus
sp. nov.
, is described from Malaysia (Borneo: Sabah ). The species is similar to
O. megaceros Fauvel, 1895
, but can be separated based on four male features: a more pointed tip on the anterior margin of the clypeus, a wider central plate on the posterior margin of sternite VIII with a carina that spans the entire width of the posterior margin of medial plate, two sharper and thinner projections on the apical orifice, and the apico-medial hook with a smaller apical tip but without the connecting scape. As a result, a total of 31 confirmed species have been recorded in Southeast Asia hitherto.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words:
Staphylinidae
,
Oxytelinae
,
Oxytelus
, Southeast Asia , Borneo ,
new species

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Oxytelus Gravenhorst, 1802
is a genus of oxyteline rove beetles that has a worldwide distribution and consists of 219 species (including 4 fossil species) by the time of this writing (personal data). The fauna in Southeast Asia was reviewed by
, in which a total of thirty valid species were documented. During my visit to the Natural History Museum, London in July 2022 , I came across three specimens collected from Borneo bearing characteristics that had not been reported in any known Bornean species. In this paper, I describe them as a new species and compare it with
O. megaceros Fauvel, 1895
, to which the new species exhibits a striking outward resemblance. Given that the redescription and illustration of
O. megaceros
have been already published in previous papers (
,
), here I only present the images of the new species.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p:
Three specimens were examined. The detailed description of specimen treatment may be found in
. The observation, measurement, and photography were performed using a Nikon SMZ18 stereomicroscope equipped with a Nikon DS-Ri2 camera and controlled through NIS-Elements D version 5.2.3 software. The program Inkscape was utilized for preparation of line-art plates. Adobe Photoshop was employed for digital post-processing of the color photos. All the types of the new species described here are deposited at the Natural History Museum, London, UK ( BMNH ).

// BMNH (E), 2005-177, H. Mendel // Oxytelus acriculiclypeatus

.

: 2♁♁, Borneo Sabah , Danum Valley , 4°58′N 117°47′E , Flight Intercept Trap ,
June 1999
// BMNH (E), 2005-177, H. Mendel // Oxytelus acriculiclypeatus
♁
PARATYPE det. LÜ
Liang, 2024 ( BMNH ).

Description. Body (
) medium-sized, glossy, dark brown to blackish. First two antennomeres, maxillary palpi, and legs yellowish brown and elytra brown and vaguely translucent. Body length about 4.5 mm .

Holotype Paratype 1 Paratype 2 Body length 4.594 4.307 4.452 Forebody length 2.183 2.140 2.337 Head length 0.625 0.800 0.862 Head width 0.849 0.824 0.871 Eye length 0.232 0.222 0.234 Temple length 0.294 0.294 0.318 Supra-antennal ridge vertex distance 0.482 0.449 0.480 Neck width 0.498 0.490 0.510 Pronotum length 0.824 0.627 0.633 Pronotum width 0.809 0.862 0.896 Elytra length 0.766 0.755 0.782 Left elytra width 0.538 0.528 0.534 Right elytra width 0.508 NA 0.555 Abdomen width 1.050 1.093 1.128

Mandible stout, falciform, strongly incurved; apex sharply pointed. Antenna ( type II) as long as or slightly longer than head and pronotum together, with apical antennomere slightly shorter than two preceding together, antennomeres 4–11 with basal dish (
).

Aedeagus (
). Median lobe elongate and slightly broader basally, ventral edge of apical orifice with two pointed processes near middle, with sclerite-like or membranous structures in apical part of median lobe; apico-medial hook with apical tip pointed and downcurved and with transverse carina behind tip, basal process short; dorsal membranous area covering most of apical part of dorsum and nearly across length of median lobe. Parameres arm-like, with apex flattened, a little broadened and rounded, with ridge on ventral and lateral surface of each piece and screw-tracked at elbow bend, at near 1/2 of apical arm situated with long seta.

Etymology. The specific epithet is derived from two Latin adjectives acriculus and
clypeatus
, referring to the sharp clypeal tip.

Remarks. This species closely resembles
O. megaceros
and was found in overlapping areas ( Lü & Zhou 2015 ). However, it can be distinguished from the latter by several male morphological features (cf. Fig. 11 in Lü & Zhou 2012, Fig. 34 in 2015): the anterior clypeal margin with a sharper tip than that of
O. megaceros
, the posterior margin of sternite VIII with a broader central plate and a carina lying across the whole width of the posterior margin of central plate, the sharper and more slender processes on the apical orifice, and the apico-medial hook with a smaller apical tip but without the connecting scape that attaches it to the body of aedeagal median lobe.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: The author thanks Dr. Maxwell Barclay (Natural History Museum, London), who provided the specimens for this study. An anonymous reviewer reviewed the earlier version of this manuscript and gave a lot of constructive suggestions, for which the author is very grateful. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (32170441) and the China Scholarship Council (202008130002).
